awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: A multifunctional metal-based nanoparticle solution for surface disinfection and decontamination
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a metal-based nanoparticle coating solution for durable antimicrobial and self-cleaning surfaces.  Disinfected and cleaned surfaces are critical to fight against microbes and to prevent infection. However, the most commonly used methods including sprays and wipes involve repeated applications of disinfectants, some containing volatile chemicals that are potentially harmful. The goal of the proposed technology is to create a durable coating on surfaces that are susceptible to microbes and contaminants. Compared with existing methods, the proposed technology improves the convenience and potency and is expected to find use in a number of applications including surface disinfection, antimicrobial and self-cleaning coatings, and wastewater treatment systems.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a metal nanoparticle coating solution to enable antimicrobial and self-cleaning surfaces.  Metal nanoparticles are broad-spectrum antimicrobial agents that can suppress growth and eliminate microbes via multiple mechanisms. Tailoring the size, shape, and surface properties of the metal nanoparticles may improve their antimicrobial potency significantly. In addition, surface modification may enable antimicrobial and self-cleaning functions in one formulation. Compared to the existing disinfection and self-cleaning methods, the proposed metal nanoparticle-integrated solution has other possible advantages including the flexibility to be a stand-alone product or to be incorporated into existing products.  The metal microparticles can also be combined with a built-in indicator for a visual readout of effectiveness or with an added external portable scanner for accurate readout and recording of effectiveness that may be linked to a smart-phone app to log the result. The proposed technology may create a durable, self-cleaning surface that protects against bacteria, viruses, fungi, and chemical contaminants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Disinfected and cleaned surfaces are critical to fight against microbes and to stop and prevent pandemic. However, the most commonly-used methods including sprays and wipes involve endless applications of disinfectants containing volatile chemicals that are potentially harmful to our body. The proposed solution in this project is to create a durable coating on surfaces that are susceptible to microbes and contaminants. This technology is expected to find use in a number of applications, including surface disinfections, antimicrobial and self-cleaning coatings, and waste water treatment systems. The project allows us to identify the market needs for the technology and its potential towards commercialization and further impact to STEM research. The team has successfully completed NSF 7-week National I-Corps program and conducted hundreds of interviews. Based on the interviews and the feedback from the market, the team was able to identify key industry partners and work on tackling the biofilm infection problems. The team also developed a new technology that can effectively eradicate microbes on surfaces, and established new connection and collaboration to explore the nanoparticle coating solution for environmental remediation.

The project involved students and faculty with STEM background, as well as a mentor with entrepreneur and technology commercialization background. The whole team working together on business development aimed to create cross-discipline broader impacts to provide solutions that integrate antimicrobial and self-cleaning multi-function into one entity. Through this project, the team has explored a broad customer range including hospitals/clinics and meat processing, packaging, and transporting facilities, industrial waste water treatment facilities, medical device manufacturers, and glass and fabrics manufacturers. The findings supported by this project led the team further our development of the antimicrobial technology and focus our research efforts in the imminent issues and problems in health care and environmental remediation. This project supported the training and professional development for two graduate students and three undergraduate students. The experience of the I-Corps program was much different from their academic training and helped them to improve their skills in communication, time management, critical thinking, and problem-solving from different aspects. The project prepared students to be competitive in the job market and to have entrepreneur mindset in research, as well as helped them making decision to stay on for STEM research more effectively. Therefore, the project improves the public health and enhances the economic competitiveness of the U.S.
